Editorial Cartoonist Speaks
On 'Life and Hard Times'
• by Jay Lechtman
The Friends of the Johns
Hopkins Library sponsored a
speech entitled "The Life and
Hard Times of an Editorial
Cartoonist," given by Mike
Lane of the Baltimore Evening
Sun, last Monday evening at
the Evergreen House on N.
Charles St.
"The first editorial cartoonist was Ben Franklin in
- 1763," remarked Lane, and
cartoonists gave us our popular
conceptions of both the
Republican and Democratic
party symbols, and even of
Santa Claus. Yet, "cartoonists
are not taken seriously," said
Lane, though adding that there
is a doctoral thesis on editorial
cartooning in the MSE Library.
"We [editorial cartoonists]
are not a serious bunch," Lane
said. "We do have a convention every year," Lane added,

but the 150 cartoonists meet in
places like Disneyworld in
Orlando, or in the Del Coronado Hotel in San Diego
(where the film Some Like It
Hot was filmed). "You won't
find us having a convention in
Toledo," he said.
One reason why Lane might
not be taken seriously is
because of his typical day:
From 7:15 a.m. to 12 p.m. he
reads the Washington Times,
Post and the Baltimore Sun,
sketches, and fools around.
Lane said, "I do for a living
what most people dream of doing, but I was training in school
for years," he joked. At noon,
he spends ten minutes with his
editor, deciding on which of his
rough
ideas
will
be
printed. ..and that's it.
The job isn't without
thought, however. An editorial
cartoon must be specific
enough to make its point, yet

general enough to be
understood, and topical enough
to be relevant. "I had this
knack of predicting the news
when I was younger, and my
editor had this knack of tearing
up my cartoons," said Lane.
Regarding the self-styled role
of the editorial cartoonist, Lane
said, "There isn't one." It's
simply "to draw cartoons and
be a part of the paper." The
cartoon is the "quick fix" and
doesn't say "here, read this,"
but "look here for a minute,"
Lane added.
When asked if changes in
politics and politicians had any
effect on his work, Lane said,
"Dull politicians make dull cartoons. This love affair with
Mayor Schaefer is really complicating my job, because
there's no crooked politics going on ...Nixon was a
Godsend."

'Frog Dances' Dissected At
Reading of Dixon's Stories
With a clear voice colored
with a twinge of a New York
accent, fiction writer Stephen
Dixon entertained a capacity
audience in the Garrett Room
with readings from his works
on Wednesday night.
The crowd, consisting mainly of undergraduates who have
read Dixon's work for their
writing seminars classes, listened to the two-time winner of the
O'Henry Memorial Award and
full-time Hopkins teacher as he
read from four of his works.
The first selection was entitled "Frog Dances" from a yet
unpublished "interconnected
collection of short stories,"
which, as Dixon explained,
forms a kind of novel that
"dissects Frog, which is what
I'm doing to this guy."
In this, like others of Dixon's
works, men and women exchange their stereotypical roles,
the men becoming affectionate
and romantic, while the women
are evasive and aggressive.
In the story Frog hopes to
find a woman with whom he
can fall in love, marry, and
have children. But like most of
Dixon's protagonists, he is
doomed to failure, and instead
only finds a woman who likes
her independence, and has
given up her children to her exhusband.
In most of Dixon's works,
sexual and occasionally violent
descriptions are important if
not key in setting the tone of
the stories, being dealt with
casually and explicitly without
euphemisms.
Dixon then introduced his
next selection, "Tastes," which
was written last June and was
inspired by, "an event that actually happened in New York."
The story is one of a rape and
murder of a student studying in
New York, and is told
simultaneously through the five
main characters.
The third selection,"A Parting," Dixon introduced by saying, "This one's a little
livelier." It compared to
"Taste" in that sex and
violence, although as widely used in both stories, did not appall the listeners, but instead
humored them.

The final reading, "Grace
Calls," displayed almost Steinian characteristics, with its two
to five word sentences, some of

A typical passage from the
story, "I read. I drink coffee.
I make lunch, I read. Car

A woman walks her dog,"
displays the boredom and

Throughout the confusion of
the story, the only stabilizing

"Grace Calls, Grace Called,"
which were randomly and
repeatedly placed throughout
the story.
After the readings Dixon
fielded questions concerning his
work and life. When asked
about his start in writing, Dixon explained, "I was a journalist, a newsman, with nothing

to do at night but drink and
read."
After writing both poetry
and fiction, Dixon explained
that "I had to make a decision"
between the two. Since, as he
saw it, his poetry was too prosaic, "too much like my fiction" he decided to "put my
poems in a plastic garbage bag
and put them on the curb for
the sanitation department to
pick up."
Dixon, a prolific writer with
eight books published in ten
years and another to come out
soon, was a meticulous reader
paying careful attention to the
tone of his reading, and
displaying a perfectionist
tendency when he repeated a
single line from a story three
times to make sure the inflection was correct.

A Closed Editorial
A little tussle we and the GRO got into recently has illustrated an interesting,
and important, and oft forgotten, point:
university organizations shouldn't—
ever—have closed meetings.
The GRO affair began when we decided at the beginning of this semester to
start covering—at the GRO's behest—
its meetings. But when we sent a
reporter, they threw him out. Part of the
meeting was going to be secret, they said,
so the News-Letter would have to leave.
We objected to that, and the GRO has
since reversed itself and passed a resolution stating that all their meetings will be
open in the future. That was clearly the
right thing to do, but this whole matter
has reminded us that a dual injustice remains: 1) while student groups that are
members of the Student Activities Commission are forbidden from having closed meetings, so-called student government groups can constantly hide from
view if they wish to, and 2) the administration constantly closes all of the
meetings of its important bodies.
Not counting the GRO, there are two
key student groups not covered by the
SAC regulations: the Student Council
and the Inter-Fraternity Council.
Although the Council, to its credit, does
not currently hold closed meetings, it was
less than a decade ago that this
newspaper's reporters were being
physically thrown out of Council
meetings. Furthermore, there is no provision in the SC's constitution prohibiting closed meetings. The IFC is far
worse: it does in fact regularly close its
meetings.

There is no defense for the IFC's closed meetings, and there would be none if
the Council were to try such a thing.
Both groups claim to represent students
in one form or another, and surely those
students have a right to know what their
representatives do.
The administration is guiltier still.
There is no reason, for example, the
meetings of the Committee on
Undergraduate Studies or the Academic
Council should be closed, as they have
been for years. Both these organizations
deal largely with academic matters such
as curriculum changes. Surely those sorts
of things aren't so important that they
must be kept secret.
We don't anticipate that the council
will try to close any of its meetings, and
we don't mean to lump it with the administration and the IFC (Even the
council doesn't deserve that company.)
But to insure that closed meetings don't
pop up in the future, the council ought
to follow the SAC's lead and amend its
own constitution to forbid closed
meetings. And what of the IFC and the
administrative committees such as the
CUS? Well, they should, but won't,
open their meetings. We doubt there is
anything we can say to convince them,
but that doesn't make them any less
wrong.
Of all places, a university ought to be
a forum for an open exchange of ideas,
not smoke-filled rooms. Hopkins' motto says that "The Truth Will Set You
Free." It surely can't do so if it is being
concealed.

Some Election Reforms
Like the swallows returning to
Capistrano, there are some things that
happen every year. Around Homewood,
one of those is some complaining that
nobody paid attention to the Student
Council elections.
For as long as we can remember,
people—most noticeably the Elections
Commission and the candidates—have
griped that the elections go largely unnoticed. This newspaper covers the
things insufficiently. Nobody (literally)
comes to the Candidates' Forum. Except
for the freshmen, far too few people
vote.
Some of that seemed to change last
year, when expanded coverage in these
pages and a tight, unpredictable threeway race for the council Presidency
livened things up.
Still, the main problem with the election process persists. There simply is not
enough time for people to become really interested in the races. Traditionally,
candidates' petitions are due on a given
Tuesday at 5 p.m. The Elections Commission then verifies the petitions, and
the official list of candidates is available
sometime Tuesday evening. Since, to be
both honest and immodest,• the News-

Letter is the main forum for publicizing
campus issues and events, many students
hear little or nothing about the elections
until that Friday's paper. And since Friday's paper is put together Wednesday
and Thursday, there is frequently too little time to cover the elections to the extent we would like.
After people read about the elections
in Friday's paper, they have only four
days until the vote—hardly enough time
for an interesting campaign to develop.
So how about a little electoral reform?
We suggest the Elections Commission
move the date petitions are due up a
week this year. Students would then have
a week-and-a-half to decide who they
want to vote for, and a true campaign
might develop. Furthermore, this
newspaper would publish twice between
the time the petitions are due and the
voting, allowing for more extensive
coverage.
We haven't suggested our proposal to
Elections Commission Chairman Scott
Turner; we merely offer it as something
to think about. It surely would hurt no
one, and the advantages would benefit
us all.

by Sujata Banerjee
No one ever said love comes
easy, but at Hopkins, students
think it is impossible. Students
speak guardedly about romance,
and while they say it is there for
, people who really try, it's not
a priority in their lives.
"It's not that love is dead,
but it takes a back seat to studying," said senior John Burke.
"People don't have to use
headaches as an excuse. They
have exams."
An anonymous senior woman
said relationships were shaped
by study habits.
"It's better not to be in the
same major—there is the competitiveness factor, and you
have to take all your classes
together," she said. She and her
boyfriend have study dates in
order to find time for each
other. Yet she has noticed people tend not to be "super
serious" since they will part
after senior year for graduate
school.
If people choose not to study

with their romantic partners
they tend to pick them just for
fun. Rumours of one-night
stands in the stacks of the MSE
abound. Senior women are
beginning to go out with
freshmen for "flings," according to the anonymous female.
"Freshmen are so wonderful
and unjaded," she said.
Toby Mordkoff, who graduated in December, says
Hopkins encourages shallow
relationships.
"It's easier to have a onenight stand than a relationship," he said. "The social
mood is horrendous. Hopkins
has gotten colder."
Mordkoff has undergone a
romantic evolution of sorts.
First he was interested in a
traditional boyfriend-girlfriend
ideal. Now he wants a "lover
with a capital L—you admit to
your sex drive, but are in a relationship where personal aspects
are not as important as sleeping
together."
He says lovers may rendezvous up to three nights a week,

but do not seek each other out
at other times for friendly
activities.
"Relationships aren't safe at
Hopkins," he said. "There's an
atmosphere of head games and
power trips."
Burke agrees there is competitiveness, especially among
men for women.
"Guys give up when one of
them makes progress with
another girl," he said. He
thinks people who aren't in
relationships are either scared
to get involved, or are busy
studying.
Although students may
sound negative about love at
Hopkins, futures do not depend on the slim pickings on
campus.
"Out of a few million guys,
there are many Mr. AlmostRights," the female said. And
she carries a copy of the Kama
Sutra in her backpack as a jest.
"At this school, I found it on
sale for 99 cents," she said.

Blowing It Off in Bologna
by Carrie Mook
Most Hopkins students know
about the graduate School of
Advanced International Studies
(SAIS), and about its Italian
campus in Bologna. What you
may not know is that each year
six to twelve Hopkins
undergraduates have the opportunity to participate in this
program.
Because the Bologna Center
is a graduate institution,
eligibility is limited to upperlevel students, particularly
juniors, majoring in history, international relations, or
political economy. Classes are
conducted in English, but an intensive class in Italian in
September gives students a
working knowledge of the
language. All students pay ,
regular Hopkins tuition plus
travel and living expenses, but
financial aid is available.
Terry Cook, one of the eight
Hopkins seniors who went on
the program last year, was enthusiastic: "All our group
adapted really well and had a
great time." She called the trip
"educational" in more ways
than one. Besides doing
graduate-level course work,
participants had a chance to
travel, to meet people from all
across America and Europe,
and to become part of the
Italian community.
The eight Homewood
students were the only
undergraduates at SAIS. They
found the classes difficult but
interesting. Most of the professors were European, and

their style of teaching took
some getting used to for the
American students. For example, they liked oral exams. But
the professors were mostly
good, and as Cook said, "If
you didn't mind working, you
had plenty of time for other
things, like travelling."
If you want to travel in Italy, Bologna is a good place to
be. Centrally located, it is an
hour and a half from Florence
and a few hours from Vienna.
It is fairly easy, and surprisingly
inexpensive for students to
take off for a long weekend and
explore. Ned Neuberger and his
friends arranged their schedules
so that alternate Thursdays and
Fridays were free, and went on
trips through Germany, Italy,
and the rest of Europe: "We
lived in the most abominable
conditions possible, and slept
on trains a couple of times to
save money, but we could do
five days for $100. It was
great!" There were schoolsponsored trips as well, including one to Poland. Apparently SAIS pays for a couple of Polish graduate students
each year in return for being
allowed a group trip.
Being in Bologna is an education in itself. SAIS can be a
world in itself, and some student made close friends in the
school community. Others went
into the city and became part of
it. Cook spent most of her free
time with Italians. She said, "I
was their American friend, and
that made me special. They got
close to me quickly."
The best part of the program

was living there. She said, "Our
apartment was beautiful. Marble floors, three bedrooms, two
terraces, half an hour's walk
from campus(there was a shuttle), and $150 a month. And the
elevator always worked!"
There were a few adventures involved in setting up housekeeping, like trying to buy a washing
machine before they learned
much Italian.
After classes,"We hung out,
said Neuberger, "Italy is a
hang-out sort of country. I
played soccer some with my
Italian friends, and we went to
the beer hall."
Cook agreed, "The osteria
was a big thing. It's sort of a
club, and people drink beer,
and someone will bring a deck
of cards, or someone will bring
a guitar and everyone sings.
Ned sang a lot. If he hadn't
brought his guitar, someone
would find one for him."
Walking and shopping were
other ways of passing time.
Window-shopping was fun, but
"don't walk into a store unless
you know more or less what
you want and plan to buy
something. If you walk around
and touch things and ask about
prices and try them on, you'd
better buy something or they'll
get irritated," Cook said.
Neuberger and Cook both
liked the program and recommend it. Any interested
sophomores should see Dr.
Goodyear at Academic Advising as soon as possible, since
the deadline for applications if

Stunning Brazil is Worth the Wait
by Steve Brett
Brazil has traveled a long,
treacherous road to reach its
current Baltimore area engagement at the Towson Twin
Cinemas. For some time, there
was a question as to whether it
would ever get to see the light
of day in this country, at least
in its current form.
Brazil was financed by Arnon Milchan, and set to be
distributed in the United States
by Universal Pictures; but when
Gilliam presented Universal
with his finished product, they
did not like what they saw. Sid
Sheinberg of Universal insisted
that the film should be reedited,
but Gilliam held firm to his
own vision of the movie. When
a stalemate was reached, Universal put Brazil on the shelf.
Gilliam, annoyed with the idea
of his film not being released in
the U.S., actually contemplated
sponsoring viewings of Brazil in
Mexico to be attended by audiences bussed in from
California.
Such drastic measures would
not be needed. A special screening of Brazil was arranged in
this country for Los Angeles
critics, who left so enthusiastic
about the work that they voted
it the best film of 1985. Universal's desire to reedit was obviously eclipsed by their visions
of dollar signs and added

prestige, so they scrambled to
have the film released in New
York and around the country in
time to have it qualify for the
Academy Awards. It is now up
for the Best Original Screenplay
and Best Art Direction Oscars;
such awards would be welldeserved indeed.
For those who are familiar
with Terry Gilliam's name but
are unable to place it, he is
primarily known for being one
sixth of Monty Python,
although he is certainly a filmmaker in his own right, with
such films as Monty Python
and the Holy Grail(co-directed
with Terry Jones), Jabberwocky, and Time Bandits to his
credit. The only Python of
American origin, Gilliam does
not appear in many of the
group's sketches but he does
keep his on-screen presence felt
by being the man behind the
Monty Python animation (see
the opening credit sequence of
"Life of Brian" for what may
be his most notable exercise in
animation to date).
As could be expected from
such a clever, colorful
animator, Gilliam presents us
with some terrifically stunning
visuals in what can be termed
his personal version of "1984."
The film
takes
place
"Sometime in the 20th century;" the scene is a
nightmarish "future world" of

sorts, but it is a future where
styles and technology were not
allowed to progress past the
forties and fifties. Mind control
is the way of life, and posters
seen throughout the film
display the philosophy of the
all-dominating Ministry of Information: "Suspicion Breeds
Confidence," "Don't Suspect a
Friend—Report Him,"_ and the
like. Computers, old-time
television, and endless paperwork characterize life in this
unnamed metropolis where
ever-present and unsightly
ducts must have some greater
purpose than the mere transfer
of hot air.
The screenplay, written by
Gilliam, Charles McKeown,
and playwright Tom Stoppard
(Rosencrantz and Gildenstern
are Dead, and more recently,
The Real Thing) details the life
of Sam Lowrie (Jonathan
Pryce), a worker in the
Ministry's
Information
Retrieval department who is
satisfied with being no more
than a number in society. The
freedom he lacks he makes up
for in his dreams, where he envisions himself a winged warior continually coming to the
fescue of a most heavenly fair
maiden.
Robert DeNiro has the
smaller role of Archibald Tuttle, a heating engineer sick of
the system. No longer willing to

deal with the limitless Central
Services paperwork, Tuttle
becomes a renegade repairman,
providing much-needed work
on people's broken air conditioning without first receiving
proper clearance from the
authorities. As a result, Tuttle
is seen as a subversive who must
be eliminated, but he always
manages to stay one step ahead
of the law. When the computer
prints out the instructions for
Tuttle's arrest, a bug in the
printer (literally) causes his
name to be printed as "Buttle"
instead, resulting in the termination of Archibald Buttle,
a poor but devoted husband
and family man.
Jill Leyton (Kim Greist), a
politically radical truck-driving
neighbor of the Buttles, wants
to correct this obvious miscarriage of "justice" before it is
too late. Her efforts bring her
to the Ministry of Information,
where she is spotted by Sam
Lowrie, who realizes that
Leyton just so happens to be a
short-haired version of the
woman of his dreams. The normally unambitious Lowrie accepts a promotion arranged by
his affluent mother (Katherine
Helmond, and, yes, those are
shoes that she wears on her
head) only so that he can gain
access to classified information
about his mystery woman. But
when Lowrie becomes obsessed

in his search for the woman he
loves, he is pegged as being a
radical himself.
Gilliam has done some
fascinating, even stunning
things with the visuals
throughout the film. I,owrie's
dream sequences are highlights,
and things reach a stunning
peak at the film's end, in an
odd sequence that flows
smoothly and beautifully from
one scene to the next. The sheer
bizarreness of much of the film,
both in storyline and imagery,
betrays the existence of a
Python in the director's chair.
But while the film is hardly
without humor, it is also not
comedy through and through,
and, without spoiling anything,
it does not end in the way you
might hope it would.
Brazil is a fine film on many
levels, and is far from being for
Monty Python fans alone. In
fact, expecting a Monty Python
comedy will only leave you
disappointed. Says Gilliam,
Brazil is "About the impossibility of escaping from
reality," and that's not exactly
a knee-slapper of a topic. But
Brazil is worth seeing, and
deserves to be seen all the same.
After all, it must be a highquality, intelligent feature; if it
wasn't, why would Universal
try to stop its release?

Dazzling 42nd Street in 4-week run at Mechanic
by Peter Oehlkers
Depending on your point of
view, spectacle is hard to come
by these days or it is overwhelming in its abundance. TV,
with its constantly growing
volume, beat, and flourescent
color provides an endless supply of spectacle; on the other
hand, there seems to be a lot
less around to be truly awed
by—less that makes you sit
back and go, "wow . .."42nd
Street is pure spectacle, of the
sort that's been missing lately.
Apparently, this show (and
this is definitely a show, not a
play) has broken all kinds of
records at the Mechanic
Theatre Box Office and it's
easy to see why—it's really a
wonderful thing to watch and
listen to. Those who came
opening night expecting dazzling original dance numbers
could not have been disappointed; those who expected
even a semblance of an intelligent plot had to have
been—but that's not the point.
To this kind of show, a plot is
simply supplementary.
What plot does exist concerns producer Julian Marsh
(played by showbiz veteran
Barry Nelson—a ringer for a
tall Earl Weaver)and his efforts
to put on a show during the
Depression. Gail Benedict plays
Peggy Sawyer, the inevitable
small town girl who comes
from nowhere to save the show

and Tony award-winner
Dolores Gray plays Dorothy
Brock, a spoiled showbiz
legend. The show's weakest
links probably lie in its casting
as both Nelson and Gray seem
far too old for their roles. For
example, there is a hint of a
romantic relationship between
Julian and Peggy which tends
to make one cringe as Nelson is
twice as old as Gail Benedict.
Also, when Peggy takes over
the leading role from Dorothy,
she fits perfectly into her
costumes—even
though
Dolores Gray is shaped like
Ethel Merman and Benedict
certainly isn't. But then again,
as Broadway continues to
decline, I imagine it is inevitable
that the real "name" stars are
going to come from farther and
farther in the past. In reality,
however, Gail Benedict makes
a far greater impression than
either Nelson or Gray, the two
"names", playing Peggy with
the exact amount of exaggerated spunk required of the
role—and there is certainly no
doubt that she can sing and
dance, and sing and dance well.
Nevertheless, 42nd Street is
most impressive for its ensemble dancing than for its individual performances. In a
way, the set pieces and musical
numbers are the real stars of the
show. The dance numbers start
out with a bang—the colorful
"Audition"—and build in
spectacularity until the
finale—"42nd Street," a

massive number with the lights
of Braodway as a backdrop. In
between these two numbers, the
musical pieces range from the
clever "Shadow Waltz,"
featuring dancing silhouettes;
to the flashy "Dames," featuring mirrors and sequins; to the
racy "Shuffle Off to Buffalo,"
featuring a newly-wed couple
and a host of lingerie-clad
"dancers." Much of the music
(written by the team of Warren
and Dubin) is familiar—
"We're in the Money,"
"Lullaby of Broadway," and
of course "42nd Street," but
most of it isn't familiar, which
is nice in many respects.
If there is a problem with this
production, it lies in the way the
obviously inferior plot interferes with the musical
qualities. Unlike .the standard
musical, the first act doesn't
end with a bang but on a down
note. In the same way, the show
doesn't really end with the
finale but on a melancholy, sentimental reprise of "42nd
Street" sung by Julian Marsh.
The writers evidentally were
trying to avoid the show
business cliches but let's face it,
a musical is hardly fine art and
pure crowd pleasing is certainly no sin.
But on the whole, the show
is great. Besides the good performances of Barry Nelson and
Dolores Gray, and especially
Gail Benedict, one is treated to
the comic talents of Denise Lor
and Don Potter. as the in-

Autobiography seems to get
away with much more than
most literary forms. Few people are not amenable to a little
philosophizing and only impatient readers insist on fast action and stylish wordplay. But
at the same time, life stories of
the rich and famous are hardly
boring. So in our time, we have
slick, heavily-marketed accounts of successes by
household names like Ferraro
and Iacocca topping the bestseller lists. Then, without any
ghost author credit in small
print, along comes Entrances,
An American Director's
Journey by the late Alan
Schneider. Mr. Schneider was
one of America's formeost
theatre directors, having done
Who's Afraid of Virginia
Woolf? among other major
plays. Entrances was to be only the first volume of his
autobiography, delivered to
Viking Penguin a scant nine
days before his death.
This book narrates an entirely different sort of success, with
vivid little scenes. The language
isn't fussy, but neither does it
read as an oral history might.
It has a quality of being
moderate, balanced between a
rich ornate style and a lean
sparse style. This complements
the content well. Mr. Schneider
is aware he is telling us a story,
in his case a true personal story,
and he is unhampered by the

writing itself.
Mr. Schneider's childhood
was filled with unhappy incidents, presented here without
melodrama, almost too easy to
read. There is a natural quality
of having gotten over trauma.
A recurring early memory is of
his mother struggling to get
cod-liver oil for the young
Alan,
then
Abram
Leopoldovitch Schneider, son
of two young doctors struggling in Revolutionary Russia.
But the child was not appreciative of this important part
of his diet...After a perilous
journey through paperwork,
his family emigrated to
America. When the other
children were evil in the way
children are, making fun of his
being Jewish and actually attacking him, he recounts that
he learned to run fast, "a skill
that later helped me as a track
man in high school and college.
Nothing is without its compensations." This exemplifies the
relative absence of emotion
throughout the book.
Later, he lived in Baltimore
and spent a great deal of time
surreptitiously reading science
fiction (then less respectable
than pornography) and watching movies. He writes that he
might have read a play or two,
but at the time his "contemporary theatre was on film."
Then he happened to be invited
to see a play. Immediately,
there began an obsession.
Mr. Schneider first attended
Johns Hopkins; his parents
believed he would follow them
into medicine. Instead, he
struggled with physics, decided
to become a journalist and then
thought to transfer to University of Michigan. He ended up

at Wisconsin, where he tried
out for many plays and was
never cast in a leading role. So
he wound up directing and
distinguishing himself for producing a dramatic adaptation
of a story without having the
legal rights to do so.
After "First Acts," Alan
enters the real world and the
book becomes a detailed
memoir of his struggling career.
He writes about his not having
held a regular job and then
usually receiving two offers at
once. He seemed to always get
two proposals and of course,
the job he did choose never
lasted long. The book describes
many events, without being too
concerned with a life
philosophy or even a
philosophy of directing.
Unfortunately, the later sections are also considerably less
interesting to read then the
glimpses of childhood. There is
less humor, less personality and
only the theatre. A few episodes
of life break up the lone introduction to the crazy world of
American drama. He loses his
virginity, gets married, has
children, suffers a few personal
losses and the show goes on.
Perhaps because there are a
multitude of characters, none
of the players in "Second Acts"
becomes three-dimensional.
Not even his wife Eugenie
Muckle takes on any
distinguishable persona. Action
takes place, but little character
development does. For an
autobiography, this is acceptable if the author reveals some
of his thoughts. Alan Schneider
does only a fair job of depicting
his inner thoughts. Odd, given
that he favored acting
motivated by internal action,

rather than acting based upon
externals.
He reveals very little about
his private life, only slightly
more about the task of directing and a word or two about
each of the dozens of notable
actors and actresses he has
worked with. As this goes on,
the parade of actors go by. Mr.
Scneider takes care to always
mention that a particular
favorite has previously worked
with him in this play or that. If
he did not append these notices
to the actors, even an attentive
reader would probably fail to
take note of these facts, each
actor being reduced to two
things, a real name and a stage
name.
"Third Acts" continues with
Waiting For Godot, a valiant
effort which was an immediate
failure in a posh Miami
playhouse not known for plays,
but for its fancy restaurant.
This production began Alan
Schneider's association with
serious drama in America. He
became the first choice as director for Beckett, Pinter and Edward Albee's work. The discussion of "meaning" in the work
of this trio is limited, with notes
here and there and references to
the immense quantity of communications between both
director and playwright used in
producing the play. Perhaps
those scraps of ideas would
have made for a more revealing
analysis of theatre.
Now and then there appears
an allusion to Mr. Schneider's
reputation for a quick and nasty
temper,
but
the
autobiography is by this time
striking for its lack of emotion.
Even the death of Mr.
Schneider's father does not carry

the full impact it should. This
is not a fault of the writing
style, but rather a result of the
book's focus. This is a book
about the theatre life of Alan
Schneider, not about the personal life of Alan Schneider.
Even so, his ideal of an
American theatre is not explored, there is only a cursory
discussion of theatre criticism
and the book is limited to the
immediate vicinity of the stag:.
This constraint is brokea,
though only occasionally.
Samuel Beckett comes alive and
there is a Buster Keaton, still
living in 1927. Despite the
limited range of what Alan
Schneider is willing to reveal,
the writing always sustains the
material, so the book is not dry
reading. This volume ends in
the late 1960s, with Alan finally established at the age of
forty-nine, directing his greatest
commercial success, a set of one
acts by Robert Anderson.
When the American public
bothers to read, light reading is
the
first
choice.
An
autobiography of this sort
would need to be superlative to
attract attention. For the reader
with catholic tastes, there are
far too many good books for
even a book reviewer to finish
in a lifetime. There are even a
fair number of well-written
biographies brought out every
year. Entrances is a welcome
break from the glossy celebrity
diary, starting off with an interesting childhood but managing only a partially satisfactory
388 pages. For almost the cost
of a show, this genuine
autobiography is recommended
to those who are attracted to its
subtitle, An American Director's Journey.

season. Coming off an impressive victory over Stevens

Tech, the Ladies team will host
a meet this Saturday against

A Closed Editorial
A little tussle we and the GRO got into recently has illustrated an interesting,
and important, and oft forgotten, point:
university organizations shouldn't—
ever—have closed meetings.
The GRO affair began when we decided at the beginning of this semester to
start covering—at the GRO's behest—
its meetings. But when we sent a
reporter, they threw him out. Part of the
meeting was going to be secret, they said,
so the News-Letter would have to leave.
We objected to that, and the GRO has
since reversed itself and passed a resolution stating that all their meetings will be
open in the future. That was clearly the
right thing to do, but this whole matter
has reminded us that a dual injustice remains: 1) while student groups that are
members of the Student Activities Commission are forbidden from having closed meetings, so-called student government groups can constantly hide from
view if they wish to, and 2) the administration constantly closes all of the
meetings of its important bodies.
Not counting the GRO, there are two
key student groups not covered by the
SAC regulations: the Student Council
and the Inter-Fraternity Council.
Although the Council, to its credit, does
not currently hold closed meetings, it was
less than a decade ago that this
newspaper's reporters were being
physically thrown out of Council
meetings. Furthermore, there is no provision in the SC's constitution prohibiting closed meetings. The IFC is far
worse: it does in fact regularly close its
meetings.

There is no defense for the IFC's closed meetings, and there would be none if
the Council were to try such a thing.
Both groups claim to represent students
in one form or another, and surely those
students have a right to know what their
representatives do.
The administration is guiltier still.
There is no reason, for example, the
meetings of the Committee on
Undergraduate Studies or the Academic
Council should be closed, as they have
been for years. Both these organizations
deal largely with academic matters such
as curriculum changes. Surely those sorts
of things aren't so important that they
must be kept secret.
We don't anticipate that the council
will try to close any of its meetings, and
we don't mean to lump it with the administration and the IFC (Even the
council doesn't deserve that company.)
But to insure that closed meetings don't
pop up in the future, the council ought
to follow the SAC's lead and amend its
own constitution to forbid closed
meetings. And what of the IFC and the
administrative committees such as the
CUS? Well, they should, but won't,
open their meetings. We doubt there is
anything we can say to convince them,
but that doesn't make them any less
wrong.
Of all places, a university ought to be
a forum for an open exchange of ideas,
not smoke-filled rooms. Hopkins' motto says that "The Truth Will Set You
Free." It surely can't do so if it is being
concealed.

Some Election Reforms
Like the swallows returning to
Capistrano, there are some things that
happen every year. Around Homewood,
one of those is some complaining that
nobody paid attention to the Student
Council elections.
For as long as we can remember,
people—most noticeably the Elections
Commission and the candidates—have
griped that the elections go largely unnoticed. This newspaper covers the
things insufficiently. Nobody (literally)
comes to the Candidates' Forum. Except
for the freshmen, far too few people
vote.
Some of that seemed to change last
year, when expanded coverage in these
pages and a tight, unpredictable threeway race for the council Presidency
livened things up.
Still, the main problem with the election process persists. There simply is not
enough time for people to become really interested in the races. Traditionally,
candidates' petitions are due on a given
Tuesday at 5 p.m. The Elections Commission then verifies the petitions, and
the official list of candidates is available
sometime Tuesday evening. Since, to be
both honest and immodest,• the News-

Letter is the main forum for publicizing
campus issues and events, many students
hear little or nothing about the elections
until that Friday's paper. And since Friday's paper is put together Wednesday
and Thursday, there is frequently too little time to cover the elections to the extent we would like.
After people read about the elections
in Friday's paper, they have only four
days until the vote—hardly enough time
for an interesting campaign to develop.
So how about a little electoral reform?
We suggest the Elections Commission
move the date petitions are due up a
week this year. Students would then have
a week-and-a-half to decide who they
want to vote for, and a true campaign
might develop. Furthermore, this
newspaper would publish twice between
the time the petitions are due and the
voting, allowing for more extensive
coverage.
We haven't suggested our proposal to
Elections Commission Chairman Scott
Turner; we merely offer it as something
to think about. It surely would hurt no
one, and the advantages would benefit
us all.

Stunning Brazil is Worth the Wait
by Steve Brett
Brazil has traveled a long,
treacherous road to reach its
current Baltimore area engagement at the Towson Twin
Cinemas. For some time, there
was a question as to whether it
would ever get to see the light
of day in this country, at least
in its current form.
Brazil was financed by Arnon Milchan, and set to be
distributed in the United States
by Universal Pictures; but when
Gilliam presented Universal
with his finished product, they
did not like what they saw. Sid
Sheinberg of Universal insisted
that the film should be reedited,
but Gilliam held firm to his
own vision of the movie. When
a stalemate was reached, Universal put Brazil on the shelf.
Gilliam, annoyed with the idea
of his film not being released in
the U.S., actually contemplated
sponsoring viewings of Brazil in
Mexico to be attended by audiences bussed in from
California.
Such drastic measures would
not be needed. A special screening of Brazil was arranged in
this country for Los Angeles
critics, who left so enthusiastic
about the work that they voted
it the best film of 1985. Universal's desire to reedit was obviously eclipsed by their visions
of dollar signs and added

prestige, so they scrambled to
have the film released in New
York and around the country in
time to have it qualify for the
Academy Awards. It is now up
for the Best Original Screenplay
and Best Art Direction Oscars;
such awards would be welldeserved indeed.
For those who are familiar
with Terry Gilliam's name but
are unable to place it, he is
primarily known for being one
sixth of Monty Python,
although he is certainly a filmmaker in his own right, with
such films as Monty Python
and the Holy Grail(co-directed
with Terry Jones), Jabberwocky, and Time Bandits to his
credit. The only Python of
American origin, Gilliam does
not appear in many of the
group's sketches but he does
keep his on-screen presence felt
by being the man behind the
Monty Python animation (see
the opening credit sequence of
"Life of Brian" for what may
be his most notable exercise in
animation to date).
As could be expected from
such a clever, colorful
animator, Gilliam presents us
with some terrifically stunning
visuals in what can be termed
his personal version of "1984."
The film
takes
place
"Sometime in the 20th century;" the scene is a
nightmarish "future world" of

sorts, but it is a future where
styles and technology were not
allowed to progress past the
forties and fifties. Mind control
is the way of life, and posters
seen throughout the film
display the philosophy of the
all-dominating Ministry of Information: "Suspicion Breeds
Confidence," "Don't Suspect a
Friend—Report Him,"_ and the
like. Computers, old-time
television, and endless paperwork characterize life in this
unnamed metropolis where
ever-present and unsightly
ducts must have some greater
purpose than the mere transfer
of hot air.
The screenplay, written by
Gilliam, Charles McKeown,
and playwright Tom Stoppard
(Rosencrantz and Gildenstern
are Dead, and more recently,
The Real Thing) details the life
of Sam Lowrie (Jonathan
Pryce), a worker in the
Ministry's
Information
Retrieval department who is
satisfied with being no more
than a number in society. The
freedom he lacks he makes up
for in his dreams, where he envisions himself a winged warior continually coming to the
fescue of a most heavenly fair
maiden.
Robert DeNiro has the
smaller role of Archibald Tuttle, a heating engineer sick of
the system. No longer willing to

deal with the limitless Central
Services paperwork, Tuttle
becomes a renegade repairman,
providing much-needed work
on people's broken air conditioning without first receiving
proper clearance from the
authorities. As a result, Tuttle
is seen as a subversive who must
be eliminated, but he always
manages to stay one step ahead
of the law. When the computer
prints out the instructions for
Tuttle's arrest, a bug in the
printer (literally) causes his
name to be printed as "Buttle"
instead, resulting in the termination of Archibald Buttle,
a poor but devoted husband
and family man.
Jill Leyton (Kim Greist), a
politically radical truck-driving
neighbor of the Buttles, wants
to correct this obvious miscarriage of "justice" before it is
too late. Her efforts bring her
to the Ministry of Information,
where she is spotted by Sam
Lowrie, who realizes that
Leyton just so happens to be a
short-haired version of the
woman of his dreams. The normally unambitious Lowrie accepts a promotion arranged by
his affluent mother (Katherine
Helmond, and, yes, those are
shoes that she wears on her
head) only so that he can gain
access to classified information
about his mystery woman. But
when Lowrie becomes obsessed

in his search for the woman he
loves, he is pegged as being a
radical himself.
Gilliam has done some
fascinating, even stunning
things with the visuals
throughout the film. I,owrie's
dream sequences are highlights,
and things reach a stunning
peak at the film's end, in an
odd sequence that flows
smoothly and beautifully from
one scene to the next. The sheer
bizarreness of much of the film,
both in storyline and imagery,
betrays the existence of a
Python in the director's chair.
But while the film is hardly
without humor, it is also not
comedy through and through,
and, without spoiling anything,
it does not end in the way you
might hope it would.
Brazil is a fine film on many
levels, and is far from being for
Monty Python fans alone. In
fact, expecting a Monty Python
comedy will only leave you
disappointed. Says Gilliam,
Brazil is "About the impossibility of escaping from
reality," and that's not exactly
a knee-slapper of a topic. But
Brazil is worth seeing, and
deserves to be seen all the same.
After all, it must be a highquality, intelligent feature; if it
wasn't, why would Universal
try to stop its release?

Dazzling 42nd Street in 4-week run at Mechanic
by Peter Oehlkers
Depending on your point of
view, spectacle is hard to come
by these days or it is overwhelming in its abundance. TV,
with its constantly growing
volume, beat, and flourescent
color provides an endless supply of spectacle; on the other
hand, there seems to be a lot
less around to be truly awed
by—less that makes you sit
back and go, "wow . .."42nd
Street is pure spectacle, of the
sort that's been missing lately.
Apparently, this show (and
this is definitely a show, not a
play) has broken all kinds of
records at the Mechanic
Theatre Box Office and it's
easy to see why—it's really a
wonderful thing to watch and
listen to. Those who came
opening night expecting dazzling original dance numbers
could not have been disappointed; those who expected
even a semblance of an intelligent plot had to have
been—but that's not the point.
To this kind of show, a plot is
simply supplementary.
What plot does exist concerns producer Julian Marsh
(played by showbiz veteran
Barry Nelson—a ringer for a
tall Earl Weaver)and his efforts
to put on a show during the
Depression. Gail Benedict plays
Peggy Sawyer, the inevitable
small town girl who comes
from nowhere to save the show

and Tony award-winner
Dolores Gray plays Dorothy
Brock, a spoiled showbiz
legend. The show's weakest
links probably lie in its casting
as both Nelson and Gray seem
far too old for their roles. For
example, there is a hint of a
romantic relationship between
Julian and Peggy which tends
to make one cringe as Nelson is
twice as old as Gail Benedict.
Also, when Peggy takes over
the leading role from Dorothy,
she fits perfectly into her
costumes—even
though
Dolores Gray is shaped like
Ethel Merman and Benedict
certainly isn't. But then again,
as Broadway continues to
decline, I imagine it is inevitable
that the real "name" stars are
going to come from farther and
farther in the past. In reality,
however, Gail Benedict makes
a far greater impression than
either Nelson or Gray, the two
"names", playing Peggy with
the exact amount of exaggerated spunk required of the
role—and there is certainly no
doubt that she can sing and
dance, and sing and dance well.
Nevertheless, 42nd Street is
most impressive for its ensemble dancing than for its individual performances. In a
way, the set pieces and musical
numbers are the real stars of the
show. The dance numbers start
out with a bang—the colorful
"Audition"—and build in
spectacularity until the
finale—"42nd Street," a

massive number with the lights
of Braodway as a backdrop. In
between these two numbers, the
musical pieces range from the
clever "Shadow Waltz,"
featuring dancing silhouettes;
to the flashy "Dames," featuring mirrors and sequins; to the
racy "Shuffle Off to Buffalo,"
featuring a newly-wed couple
and a host of lingerie-clad
"dancers." Much of the music
(written by the team of Warren
and Dubin) is familiar—
"We're in the Money,"
"Lullaby of Broadway," and
of course "42nd Street," but
most of it isn't familiar, which
is nice in many respects.
If there is a problem with this
production, it lies in the way the
obviously inferior plot interferes with the musical
qualities. Unlike .the standard
musical, the first act doesn't
end with a bang but on a down
note. In the same way, the show
doesn't really end with the
finale but on a melancholy, sentimental reprise of "42nd
Street" sung by Julian Marsh.
The writers evidentally were
trying to avoid the show
business cliches but let's face it,
a musical is hardly fine art and
pure crowd pleasing is certainly no sin.
But on the whole, the show
is great. Besides the good performances of Barry Nelson and
Dolores Gray, and especially
Gail Benedict, one is treated to
the comic talents of Denise Lor
and Don Potter. as the in-

Entrances, An American Director's Journey.
by Alan Schneider

$25.00. 338 pages.

Autobiography seems to get
away with much more than
most literary forms. Few people are not amenable to a little
philosophizing and only impatient readers insist on fast action and stylish wordplay. But
at the same time, life stories of
the rich and famous are hardly
boring. So in our time, we have
slick, heavily-marketed accounts of successes by
household names like Ferraro
and Iacocca topping the bestseller lists. Then, without any
ghost author credit in small
print, along comes Entrances,
An American Director's
Journey by the late Alan
Schneider. Mr. Schneider was
one of America's formeost
theatre directors, having done
Who's Afraid of Virginia
Woolf? among other major
plays. Entrances was to be only the first volume of his
autobiography, delivered to
Viking Penguin a scant nine
days before his death.
This book narrates an entirely different sort of success, with
vivid little scenes. The language
isn't fussy, but neither does it
read as an oral history might.
It has a quality of being
moderate, balanced between a
rich ornate style and a lean
sparse style. This complements
the content well. Mr. Schneider
is aware he is telling us a story,
in his case a true personal story,
and he is unhampered by the

writing itself.
Mr. Schneider's childhood
was filled with unhappy incidents, presented here without
melodrama, almost too easy to
read. There is a natural quality
of having gotten over trauma.
A recurring early memory is of
his mother struggling to get
cod-liver oil for the young
Alan,
then
Abram
Leopoldovitch Schneider, son
of two young doctors struggling in Revolutionary Russia.
But the child was not appreciative of this important part
of his diet...After a perilous
journey through paperwork,
his family emigrated to
America. When the other
children were evil in the way
children are, making fun of his
being Jewish and actually attacking him, he recounts that
he learned to run fast, "a skill
that later helped me as a track
man in high school and college.
Nothing is without its compensations." This exemplifies the
relative absence of emotion
throughout the book.
Later, he lived in Baltimore
and spent a great deal of time
surreptitiously reading science
fiction (then less respectable
than pornography) and watching movies. He writes that he
might have read a play or two,
but at the time his "contemporary theatre was on film."
Then he happened to be invited
to see a play. Immediately,
there began an obsession.
Mr. Schneider first attended
Johns Hopkins; his parents
believed he would follow them
into medicine. Instead, he
struggled with physics, decided
to become a journalist and then
thought to transfer to University of Michigan. He ended up

at Wisconsin, where he tried
out for many plays and was
never cast in a leading role. So
he wound up directing and
distinguishing himself for producing a dramatic adaptation
of a story without having the
legal rights to do so.
After "First Acts," Alan
enters the real world and the
book becomes a detailed
memoir of his struggling career.
He writes about his not having
held a regular job and then
usually receiving two offers at
once. He seemed to always get
two proposals and of course,
the job he did choose never
lasted long. The book describes
many events, without being too
concerned with a life
philosophy or even a
philosophy of directing.
Unfortunately, the later sections are also considerably less
interesting to read then the
glimpses of childhood. There is
less humor, less personality and
only the theatre. A few episodes
of life break up the lone introduction to the crazy world of
American drama. He loses his
virginity, gets married, has
children, suffers a few personal
losses and the show goes on.
Perhaps because there are a
multitude of characters, none
of the players in "Second Acts"
becomes three-dimensional.
Not even his wife Eugenie
Muckle takes on any
distinguishable persona. Action
takes place, but little character
development does. For an
autobiography, this is acceptable if the author reveals some
of his thoughts. Alan Schneider
does only a fair job of depicting
his inner thoughts. Odd, given
that he favored acting
motivated by internal action,

rather than acting based upon
externals.
He reveals very little about
his private life, only slightly
more about the task of directing and a word or two about
each of the dozens of notable
actors and actresses he has
worked with. As this goes on,
the parade of actors go by. Mr.
Scneider takes care to always
mention that a particular
favorite has previously worked
with him in this play or that. If
he did not append these notices
to the actors, even an attentive
reader would probably fail to
take note of these facts, each
actor being reduced to two
things, a real name and a stage
name.
"Third Acts" continues with
Waiting For Godot, a valiant
effort which was an immediate
failure in a posh Miami
playhouse not known for plays,
but for its fancy restaurant.
This production began Alan
Schneider's association with
serious drama in America. He
became the first choice as director for Beckett, Pinter and Edward Albee's work. The discussion of "meaning" in the work
of this trio is limited, with notes
here and there and references to
the immense quantity of communications between both
director and playwright used in
producing the play. Perhaps
those scraps of ideas would
have made for a more revealing
analysis of theatre.
Now and then there appears
an allusion to Mr. Schneider's
reputation for a quick and nasty
temper,
but
the
autobiography is by this time
striking for its lack of emotion.
Even the death of Mr.
Schneider's father does not carry

the full impact it should. This
is not a fault of the writing
style, but rather a result of the
book's focus. This is a book
about the theatre life of Alan
Schneider, not about the personal life of Alan Schneider.
Even so, his ideal of an
American theatre is not explored, there is only a cursory
discussion of theatre criticism
and the book is limited to the
immediate vicinity of the stag:.
This constraint is brokea,
though only occasionally.
Samuel Beckett comes alive and
there is a Buster Keaton, still
living in 1927. Despite the
limited range of what Alan
Schneider is willing to reveal,
the writing always sustains the
material, so the book is not dry
reading. This volume ends in
the late 1960s, with Alan finally established at the age of
forty-nine, directing his greatest
commercial success, a set of one
acts by Robert Anderson.
When the American public
bothers to read, light reading is
the
first
choice.
An
autobiography of this sort
would need to be superlative to
attract attention. For the reader
with catholic tastes, there are
far too many good books for
even a book reviewer to finish
in a lifetime. There are even a
fair number of well-written
biographies brought out every
year. Entrances is a welcome
break from the glossy celebrity
diary, starting off with an interesting childhood but managing only a partially satisfactory
388 pages. For almost the cost
of a show, this genuine
autobiography is recommended
to those who are attracted to its
subtitle, An American Director's Journey.
